kate.pederson_: I found myself in a similar situation a few years ago. I was recently divorced after a really rough split. I was stressed to the max at the thought of facing his family and going through the emotions of it all. I was pleasantly surprised at how much his family appreciated me being there. It was cathartic for me, and give me some closure with his family as well. Big hugs lady. You'll be glad you went when all is said and done. ❤❤
amy_fay: I am 30, but sadly have a lot of experience here. So much so that I can say I've tried different things. What I've learned, beyond any doubt, is that the best thing you can do is show up and get okay with things sucking. Give permission and space for everything to feel shitty, but stay close. Acknowledge that it's bullshit and it sucks and you'll still be there even though you don't have anything to say that you think might magically make things feel better. Then, in three weeks or four weeks, when all the food that was brought has been eaten (I'm southern) and the flowers have died, still be there, being you (the same you you've always been, no surprises).
hayleygolightly_: 💔😔 sending you some good vibes and a big ass hug, lady.
so_cal_belle: You are so completely open and honest and I'm so sorry you have to wade through the emotional swamp right now. Truth? You got this. Don't worry about the words. Just be there. Keep being so openly and honestly you. You are a beautiful soul. You can't lose yourself if you are being yourself. ❤

fourletterwordcards: My ex husband had a heart attack while we were in the process of divorcing. He called me while he was waiting to be seen in the ER, a wait that took 2 hours, while I continually told him to tell them he was having a heart attack. He was only 34 at the time and it was terrifying. I felt like his heart attack was my fault, even though it wasn't. I stayed at our place for a month taking care of him afterwards, because it was the right thing for me to do. You are doing the right thing for you, by going and supporting him. Your love doesn't stop, just because you are divorcing, it just changes. It's hard to know how to act, but just be yourself. Be there, show him kindness, empathy and love. It will be okay, for both of you.
